editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it was lately Acted by the Company of the Reuels.
LONDON, Printed by B. A. for Thomas Iones, and are to bee ſold at his ſhop in Chancery-lane, ouer-againſt the Roles, and in Weſtminſter Hall.

div.head: TO MY HONOVRED friend, maſter Thomas May, vpon his Comedy, The Heire.
div.l: THe Heire being borne, was in his tender age
Rockt in the Cradle of a priuate Stage,
Where lifted vp by many a willing hand,
The child doth from the firſt day fairely ſtand,
Since, hauing gathered ſtrength, he dares preferre
His ſteps into the publicke Theater
The World: where he diſpaires not but to find
A doome from men more able, but leſſe kind.
I but his Vſher am, yet if my word
May paſſe, I dare be bound he will afford
Things muſt deſerue a welcome, it well knowne
Such as beſt writers would haue wiſht their owne.
You ſhall obſerue his words in order meete,
And often ſtealing on, with equall feete
Slide into equall numbers, with ſuch grace
As each word had beene moulded for that place.
You ſhall perceiue an amorous paſſion, ſpun
Into ſo ſmooth a web, as had the ſunne,
When he purſu'd the ſwiftly flying Maid,
Courted her in ſuch language ſhe had ſtaid,
A loue ſo well expreſt muſt be the ſame,
The Author felt himſelfe from his faire flame.
The whole plot doth like it ſelfe diſcloſe
Through the fiue Acts, as doth a Looke, that goes
With letters, for till euery one be knowne,
The Lock's as faſt as if you had found none.
And where his ſportiue Muſe doth draw a thred
Of mirth, chaſt Matrons may not bluſh to reade.
〈◊〉 haue I thought it fitter to reueale
〈◊〉 want of art (deare friend) then to conceale
〈…〉 It did appea • e I did not meane
〈…〉 thy well-wrought Comicke-Sceane,
〈…〉 might iudge my 〈◊〉 rather to be,
〈…〉 my ſelfe, th •• giue it thee;
〈…〉 thee none but what thou haſt

〈…〉
▪ and what muſt my faint breath outlaſt.
〈…〉 this garment (though 〈…〉 be
〈…〉 meaſure) onely made for thee,
〈…〉 to 〈◊〉 , 'tis cauſe th • ſtuffe
〈…〉 allow • d me, was not large enough.

div.head: AN EXCELLENT COMEDY CALLED the Heire.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Haſt thou divulg'd the newes
That my ſonne dy'd at Athens.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Yes my Lord,
With euery circumſtance, the time, the place,
And manner of his death; that it is beleeu'd
And told for newes with as much confidence
As if twere writ in Gallobelgicus.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That's well, that's very well, now Roſcio
Followes my part, I muſt expreſſe a griefe
Not vſuall, not like a well left heire
For his dead father, or a luſty Widdow
For her old husband, muſt I counterfeit,
But in a deeper, a farre deeper ſtraine
Weepe like a Father for his onely ſonne,
Is not that hard to doe, ha, Roſcio?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Oh no my Lord,
Not for your skill, has not your Lordſhip ſeene
A player perſonate Ieronimo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: By th'maſſe tis true, I haue ſeen the knaue paint griefe
In ſuch a liuely colour, that for falſe
And acted paſſion he has drawne true teares
From the ſpectators eyes, Ladyes in the boxes
Kept time with ſighes, and teares to his ſad accents
As had he truely bin the new man he ſeemd.
Well then Ile neere diſpaire; but tell me thou
Thou that haſt ſtill beene priuy to my boſome,
How will this proiect take?

sp.speaker: Roſc.
sp.l: Rarely my Lord,
• hen now my thinkes, I ſee your Lordſhips houſe
〈◊〉 with ſuitors of the nobleſt ranke,
And my yong Lady your ſuppoſed Heire
〈◊〉 more with woing then the Grecian Queene
In the long abſence of her wandring Lord.
There • s not a ruinous nobility
In all this kingdome, but conceiues a hope
Now to • ebuild his fortunes on this match.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thoſe are not they I looke for, no, my ne ••
Are ſpread for other game, the rich and greedy
Thoſe that haue wealth enough, yet gape for more
They are for me,

sp.speaker: Roſ
sp.l: Others will come my Lord,
All ſorts of fiſh will preſſe vpon your nets,
Then in your Lordſhips wiſedome it muſt lie
To cull the great ones, and reiect the frie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay feare not that, there's none ſhall haue acceſſe
To ſee my daughter, or to ſpeake to her,
But ſuch as I approue, and ayme to catch.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The ieſt will be, my Lord, when you ſhall ſee
How your aſpiring ſuitors will put on
The face of greatneſſe, and bely their fortunes
Conſume themſelues in ſhew, waſting like Merchants
Their preſent wealth in rigging a fayre ſhip
For ſome ill venture de voyage, that vndoes vm.
Here comes a youth with letters from the Court,
Bought of ſome fauourite at ſuch a price
As will for euer ſinke him, yet alas
• all's to no purpoſe, he muſt looſe the prize.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: This was a ieſt well thought of, the conceit
Will feed me fat, with ſport that it ſhall make,
Beſides the large aduentures it brings home
Vnto my daughter. How now. enter ſeruant

sp.p: My Lord, Count Virro is come to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Conduct him in; So, ſo, it takes already
See Roſcio ſee, this is the very man
My proiect aymd at, the rich Count that knowe •
No end of his large wealth, yet gapes for more
There was no other loadſtone could attract
His Iron heart, for could beauty haue mou'd him,
Nature has beene no niggard to my girle,
But I muſt to my griefe, here comes the Count.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Is your Lord a ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No Sir.
I thinke not, my Lord, Count Virro.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.p: How doe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do intreat your Lordſhip pardon, my griefe and ſome want of ſleepe haue made mee at this time vnmannerly, not fit to entertaine gueſts of your worth.

sp.speaker: Vir
sp.p: Alas Sir I know your griefe.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Twas that that fetcht you hither. aſide.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Y'haue loſt a worthy and a hopefull ſonne,
But heauen that alwayes giues, will ſometimes take
And that the beſt, there is no balſome left vs
To cure ſuch wounds as theſe but patience,
There's no diſputing with the acts of heauen,
But if there were, in what could you accuſe
Thoſe powers that elſe haue beene ſo liberall to you,
And left you yet one comfort in your age:
A faire and vertuous daughter.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Now it beginnes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Your blood is not extinct, nor your age childleſſe, from that fayre branch thats left may come much fruite to glad poſteritie, thinke on that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay heauen forbid I ſhould repine at what the
Iuſtice of thoſe powers ordaine, it has pleaſd
Them to confine my care onely to one, and to
See her well beſtowd is all the comfort I now
Muſt looke for, but if it had pleaſd heauen that
My ſonne, ah my Eugenio. he weepes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Alas good Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Fore heauen he does it rarely.

sp.speaker: Vir,
sp.l: But Sir, remember your ſelfe, remember your
Daughter, let not your griefe for the dead make
You forget the liuing, whoſe hopes, and fortunes
Depend vpon your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh my good Lord, you neuer had a ſoone.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Vnleſſe they were baſtards, and for them no
Doubt but he has done as other Lords do.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And therefore cannot tell what tis to looſe
A ſonne, a good ſonne, and an onely ſonne.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I would, my Lord, I could as well redreſſe
As I can take compaſſion of your griefe
You ſhould ſoone finde an eaſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray Pardon me my Lord, if I forget my ſelfe toward you at this time, if it pleaſe you viſite my houſe ofter you ſhall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You would faine ſleepe my Lord, Ile take my leaue •• auen ſend you comfort, I ſhall make bold ſhortly to viſite you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You ſhall be wondrous welcome,

Wait on my Lord out there.
exit Virr • .
So now he's gone, how thinkſt thou Roſcio,
Will not this Gudgeon bite?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No doubt my Lord,
So faire a bayte would catch a cunning fiſh.
And ſuch a one is he, he euer lou'd
The beauty of my girle, but thats not it
Can draw the earth bred thoughts of his groſſe ſoule
Gold is the God of his idolatry,
〈◊〉 hope of which Ile feed him, till at length
I make him faſten, and Ixion like
For his lou'd Iuno graſpe an empty clowd.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: How ſtands my yong Lady affected to him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: There's all the difficulty, we muſt win her to loue 〈◊〉 , I doubt the peeuiſh Gyrle will thinke him too 〈◊〉 , he's well neere threeſcore: in this buſineſſe I muſt • eaue ſomewhat to thy wit and care, prayſe him beyond all meaſure.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip euer found me truſty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If thou effect it, I will make thee happy. exeunt

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Eugenios ſiſter then is the rich heire
By his deceaſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yes, and the faire one too,
She needs no gloſſe that fortune can ſet on her,
Her beauty of it ſelfe were prize enough
To make a king turne begger for.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hoy day,
What in loue Clerimont, I lay my life tis ſo,
Thou couldſt not praiſe her with ſuch paſſion elſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know not, but I ſlept well enough laſt night,
But if thou ſawſt her once, I would not giue
A farthing for thy life, I tell thee Philocles
One fight of her would make thee cry, ay me,
Sigh, and looke pale, me thinkes I do imagine
How like an Idolatrous louer thou wouldſt looke
Through the eye-lids, know no body.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Tis very well, but how did your worſhip ſcape
Youe haue ſeene her.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: True, but I haue an
Antidote, and I can teach it thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: When
I haue need on't Ile deſire it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And twill
Be worth thy learning, when thou ſhalt ſee the
Tyranny of that ſame ſeuruy boy, and what fooles
He makes of vs; ſhall I deſcribe the beaſt?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What beaſt?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: A louer.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Doe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Then to be briefe, I will paſſe ouer the opinion of your ancient fathers, as likewiſe thoſe ſtrange Loues ſpoken of in the Authenticke hiſtories of chiualrie Amadis du Gaule, Pariſmus, the Knight of the Sunne, or the witty Knight Don Quixot de la Manca, where thoſe braue men, neither Enchantments, Gyants, Wind-mils, nor flockes of ſheepe could vanquiſh, are made the trophyes of tryumphing loue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Prithee come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
Neither will I mention the complaints of Sir Guy for the faire Phelis, nor the trauels of Pariſmus for the loue of the beautious Laurana, nor laſtly, the moſt ſad pennance of the ingenious knight Don Quixot vpon the mountains of Scienna Morenna, moou • d by the vniuſt diſdaine of the Lady Dulcinea del Toboſo,
〈◊〉 or our moderne Authors, I
will not ſo much as name them, no not that excellent treatiſe of Tullies Loue, written by the Maſter of Art.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I would thou wouldeſt paſſe ouer this paſſing ouer of Authors, and ſpeake thine owne iudgement.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why then to be briefe, I thinke a Louer lookes like an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I can deſcribe him better then ſo my ſelfe, he lookes like a man that had ſitten vp at Cards all night, or a ſtale Drunkard wakened in the middeſt of his ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But Philocles, I would not haue thee ſee this Lady, ſhe has a bewitching looke.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How dareſt thou venture man, what ſtrange medicine haſt thou found, Ouid neere taught it thee, I doubt I gueſſe thy remedy, for loue, goe to a bawdy houſe or ſo, iſt not?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Faith, and that's a good way I can tell you, we yonger brothers are beholding to it, alas wee muſt not fall in loue and chooſe whom wee like beſt, wee haue no Ioyntures for vm, as you bleſt heires can haue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well I haue found you Sir, and prithee tell me, how got'ſt thou Wenches?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why I can want no Panders, I lye in the Conſtables houſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And there you may whoore by authority,
But Clerimont, I doubt this Parragon
That thou ſo praiſeſt, is ſome il fauoured Wench
Whom thou wouldſt haue me laugh at for commending.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By heauen I ſpoke in earneſt, truſt your eyes,
Ile ſhew you her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How canſt thou doe it?
Thou know'ſt this Ladies father is to mine
A deadly enemy, nor is his houſe,
Open to any of our kindred.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's no matter,
My lodging's the next doore to this Lords houſe,
And my backe Window lookes into his Garden,
There euery morning faire Leucothoe,
(For ſo I heare her nam'd) walking alone,
To pleaſe her ſenſes makes Aurora bluſh,
To ſee on brighter then her 〈◊〉 appeare.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
Well I will ſee her the ••
▪ Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Yet for her ſake be aduiſed better Sir,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Impudent Raſcall, canſt looke me i'th face,
And know how thou haſt wrong'd me, thou haſt
Diſhonoured my Daughter, made a whoore on her.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Gentle Sir,
The wrong my loue has made to your faire Daughter
Tis now too late to wiſh vndone againe,
But if you pleaſe, it may be yet clos'd vp
Without diſhonour, I will marry her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Marry her, ſhe has a hot catch of that, marry a Begger, what Iointure canſt thou make her?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Sir I am poore I muſt confeſſe,
Fortune has bleſt you better, but I ſweare
By all things that can bind, twas not your wealth
Was the foundation of my true built loue,
It was her ſingle vncompounded ſelfe,
Her ſelfe without addition that I lou'd,
Which ſhall for euer in my ſight outweigh
All other womens fortunes, and themſelues,
And were I great, as great as I could wiſh
My ſelfe for her aduancement, no ſuch barre
As Fortunes inequality ſhould ſtand
Betwixt our loues.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Good Father heare me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Doſt thou not bluſh to call me father, Strumpet Ile make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But heare me
Sir, my ſhame will be your owne.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No more I ſay, Franciſco leaue my houſe, I charge You come not heere.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I muſt obey and will,
Deare Luce be conſtant.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Till death

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Here's a fine wedding towards, the
Bridegroome when he comes for his bride,
Shall find her great with child by another man,
Paſſion a me minion, how haue you hid it ſo long?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fearing your anger Sit, I ſtriu'd to hide it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Hide it one day more then, or be damn'd,
Hide it till Shallow be married to thee,
And then let him do his worſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Sir I ſhould too much wrong him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Wrong him, there bee great Ladies haue done the like, tis no newes to ſee a bride with childe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Then be wiſe, lay the child to him, he's a rich man, tother's a beggar.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I dare not Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do it I ſay, and he ſhall father it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He knowes he neuer touch me Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thats all one, lay it to him, weele out face him tis his: but harke, he is comming, I heare the Muſicke, ſweare thou wilt doe thy beſt to make him thinke tis his, ſweare quickly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I doe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Go ſtep aſide, and come when thy que is, thou ſhalt heare vs talke. Luce aſide.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Morrow Father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sonne bridegroome welcome, you haue beene lookt for here.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: My Tayler a little diſappointed me, but is my Bride ready.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes long ago, but you and I will talke a little, ſend in your Muſicke.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Go wait within, and tell me father, did ſhe not
Thinke it long till I came.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.l: I warrant
Her ſhe did, ſhe loues▪ you not a little.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay that I dare ſweare, ſhe has giuen me many
Taſts of her affection.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What before you
Were marryed.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I meane, in the way
Of honeſty father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay that I doubt,
Yong wits loue to be trying, and to ſay
Truth, I ſee not how a woman can deny a man
Of your youth and perſon vpon thoſe tearmes,
Youle not be knowne ont now.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I haue kiſt
Her or ſo.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come, come, I know you are no
Foole, I ſhould thinke you a very Aſſe, nay I tell
You plainely, I ſhould be loth to marry my
Daughter to you if I thought you had not tride
Her in ſo long acquaintance, but you haue tride
Her, and ſhe poore ſoule could not deny you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Ha ha hae.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Faith tell me ſonne, tis but a
Merry queſtion, ſhe's yours.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Vpon my
Virginity father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Sweare not by that,
Ile nere beleeue you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why then as I am
A Gentleman I neuer did it that I remember.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That you remember, oh iſt thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Heele take it vpon him preſently.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: You haue beene ſo familiar with her,
You haue forgot the times, but did you neuer
Come in halfe fudled, and then in a kinde humour,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Indeed I was wont to ſerue my mothers maide • ſo when I came halfe foxt as you ſayd, and then next morning I ſhould laugh to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why there it goes, I thought to haue chid you ſonne Shallow, I knew what you had done, tis too apparant, I would not haue people take notice of it pray God ſhe hide her great belly as ſhe goes to Church to day.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Why father is ſhe with child?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As if you knew not that, fie, fie, leaue your diſſembling now.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Sure it cannot be mine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How's this, you would not make my daughter a whore, would you? this is but to try if you can ſtirre my choller, your wits haue ſtrange trickes, do things ouer night when you are merry, and then deny vm. But ſtay, here ſhe comes alone, ſtep aſide, ſhe ſhall not ſeevs,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Ah my deare Shallow, thou needſt not haue made
Such haſt, my heart thou knoweſt was firme enough
To thee, but I may blame my owne fond loue,
That could not deny thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: She's with child indeed, it ſwels,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You would not beleeue me, tis a good wench,
She does it handſomely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But yet I know if
Thou hadſt bin thy ſelfe, thou wouldſt neere haue
Offered it, twas drinke that made thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Yes ſure, I was drunke when I did it, for I had
Forgot it▪ I lay my life twill proue a girle
Becauſe twas got in drinke.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am aſhamd to ſee any body.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Alas poore wretch, go comfort her, Luce.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sweet heart, nay neuer bee aſhamd, I was a little too haſty, but Ile make thee amends, weele bee marryed preſently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Be cheery Luce, you were man and wife before, it wanted but the ceremony of the Church, and that ſhall be preſently done.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I I, ſweet heart, as ſoone as may be.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But now I thinke ont ſonne Shallow, your wedding muſt not now be publicke, as we entended it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Becauſe I would not haue people take notice of this fault, weele go to Church, onely we three, the Miniſter and the Cleark, thats witneſſes enough, ſo the time being vnknowne, people will thinke you were marryed before.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But will it ſtand with my worſhip to be married in priuate.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the greateſt do it, when they haue bene 〈◊〉 before hand, there is no other way to ſaue your bri • es credite.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come lets about it preſently.
This is cloſd vp beyond our wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am vndone, vnleſſe, thy wit Franciſco,
Can find ſome meanes to free me from this foole,
Who would haue thought the ſot could be ſo groſſe
To take vpon him what he neuer did,
To his owne ſhame, Ile ſend to my Franciſco,
And I muſt looſe no time, for I am dead,
If not deliuered from this loathed bed.

div.head: Actus ſecundus.
div.stage: Enter Philocles, Clerimont at the window.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: SEE Philocles, yonders that happy ſhade,
That often vailes the faire Lucothoe,
And this her vſuall howre, ſheele not be long,
Then thou ſhalt tell me, if ſo rare an obiect
Ere bleſt thine eyes before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, I would ſee her once,
Wert but to try thy iudgement Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And when thou doeſt, remember what I told thee,
I would not be ſo ſicke, but ſoft looke to thy heart,
Yonder ſhe comes, and thats her waiting woman.
sp.stage: Leucothoe and Pſecas in the garden.
sp.l: Now gaze thy fill, ſpeake man how likeſt thou her.

sp.speaker: Pſecas.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What flower was that
That thou wert telling ſuch a ſtory of
Laſt night to me.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Tis call Narciſſus Madam▪
It beares the name of that too beautious boy,
That loſt himſelfe by louing of himſelfe,
Who viewing in afaire and criſtall ſtreame
Thoſe lips that onely he could neuer kiſſe,
Dotes on the ſhadow, which to reach in vaine
Striuing, he drwones thus ſcorning all beſide
For the loued ſhadow the fairer ſubſtance dyde.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Fie fie, I like not theſe impoſſible tales,
A man to fall in loue with his owne ſhadow,
And died for loue, it is moſt ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Madam I know not, I haue often ſeene
Both men and women court the looking glaſſe
With ſo much ſeeming contentation,
That I could thinke this true, nay weare it about vm
As louers do their Miſtreſſe counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Tha • s not for loue, but to correct their beauties
And draw from others admiration,
For all the comfort that our faces giue
Vnto our ſelues is but reflection
Of that faire likeing that another takes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I would we were a little neerer vm
We migh • but heare what talke theſe wenches haue
When they are alone, I warrant ſome good ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Tis happineſſe enough for me to ſee
The motion of her lips.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I • aith iſt there abouts.
Why Philocles, what loſt already man,
Strooke dead with one poore glance, looke vp for ſhame
And tell me how thou likeſt my iudgement now,
Now thou doeſt ſee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ah Cleremont too well,
Too well I ſee what I ſhall neuer taſte,
You Ladies beautie: ſhe muſt needs be cruell
(Though her faire ſhape deny it) to the ſonne
Of him that is her fathers enemy,
That, Cleremont, that fatall difference
Checkes my deſire, and ſinkes my riſing hopes,
But loue's a torrent violent if ſtopt,
And I am deſperately mad: I muſt
• muſt be hers, or elſe I muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Containe that paſſion that will elſe ouerwhelme
All vertue in you, all that is called man,
And ſhould be yours, take my aduice my heart
My life to ſecond you, let vs conſult,
You may find time to ſpeake to her and woe her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: May, nay I will in ſpite of deſtinie,
〈◊〉 women and faint hearted fooles complaine
In languiſhing diſpayre, a manly loue
Dares ſhew it ſelfe and preſſe to his deſires
Through thickeſt troopes of horid oppoſites,
Were there a thouſand waking Dragons ſet
To keepe that golden fruit: I would attempt
To plucke and taſte it, tis the danger crownes
A braue atchieuement: what if I ſhould goe
And boldly wooe her in her fathers houſe
In ſpite enmity, what could they ſay?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Twere madneſſe that not wiſedome raſh attempts
Betray the meanes, but neuer worke the end.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She would not hate a man for louing her,
Or if ſhe did, better be once deemed
Then liue for euer hapleſſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But take time,
The ſecond thoughts our wiſe men ſay are beſt.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Delaye's a double death, no I haue thought
A meanes, that ſtraight Ile put in execution,
Ile write a Letter to her preſently,
Take how it will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A Letter, who ſhall carry it?

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.p: Ile tell thee when I haue done, haſt thou Pen and Inke in thy Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, there is one vpon the Table, Ile ſtay here at the window, and watch whether ſhe ſtay or not, what a ſudden change is this.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Did not count Virro promiſe to be heare
To day at dinner.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Yes Madame that he did, and I dare ſweare
He will not breake.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: He needes not, he is rich enough, vnleſſe
Hee ſhould breake in knauery, as ſome of our M ••• hants doe now adayes.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Breake promiſe Madame I meane, & that he will not
For your ſake, you know his buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I would I did not, he might ſpare his paines
And that vnuſuall coſt, that he beſtowes
In pranking vp himſelfe, and pleaſe me better
He would not pleaſe his Taylor and his Barbar,
For they got more for your ſake by their Lord
Then they got this twenty yeeres before.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ah Pſecas, Pſecas, can my father thinke
That I can loue Count Virro, one ſo old
(That were enough to make a match vnfit)
But one ſo baſe, a man that neuer loued
For any thing called good, but droſſe and pelfe,
One that would neuer, had my brother liued
Haue mooued this ſute, no I can neuer loue him,
But canſt thou keepe a ſecret firmely Pſecas.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.p: Doubt me not Madame.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Well Ile tell thee then,
I loue, alas, I dare not ſay I loue him,
But there's a yong and noble Gentleman,
Lord Euphues ſonne, my fathers enemy.
A man whom natures prodigality
Stretcht euen to enuy in the making vp,
Once from a Window my pleaſed eye beheld
This youthfull Gallant as he rode the ſtreete,
On a coruetting Courſer, who it ſeemed
Knew his faire loade, and with a proud diſdaine
Checkt the baſe earth, my father being by
I ask't his name, he told me Philocles,
The ſonne and Heyre of his great enemy:
Iudge Pſecas then, how my deuided breſt,
Suffered betweene two meeting contraries,
Hatred and Loue, but Loues a deity,
And muſt preuaile againſt mortals, whoſe command

Not
• oue himſelfe could euer yet withſtand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What is the letter done already, I ſee theſe Louers haue nimble inuentions, but how will you ſend it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What a queſtion's that, ſeeſt thou this ſtone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ah, then I ſee your drift, this ſtone muſt guide your
Fleeting Letter in the Ayre, and carry it to that
Faire Marke you ayme at.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hard by her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I think you would not hit her with ſuch ſtones as this,
Lady looke to your ſelfe, he that now throwes one
Stone at you, hopes to hit you with two.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But prethee tell mee what doeſt thinke this Letter may doe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Well I hope,
Tis ten to one this Lady oft hath ſeene you,
You neuer liued obſcure in Syracuſe,
Nor walk'd the ſtreetes vnknowne, and who can tell
What place you beare in her affections,
Lou'd or miſlik'd; if bad, this letter ſent,
Will make her ſhew her ſcorne, if otherwiſe,
Feare not a womans wit, ſheele find a time
To anſwere your kind Letter, and expreſſe
What you deſire ſhe ſhould, then ſend it boldly,
You haue a fairer make there.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Cupid guide my arme,
Oh be as iuſt blind God as thou art great,
And with that powerfull hand, that golden ſhaft
That I was wounded, wound you tender breſt,
There is no ſaluē but that, no cure for me,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See what a wonder it ſtrikes vm in, how it ſhould come.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Sheele wonder more to ſee what man it comes from.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I like her well, yet ſhe is not afraid to open it:
She ſtarts, ſtay marke her action when ſhee has read the Letter.

body.l: "LEt it wrong this Letter that it came,
"From one that trembled to ſubſcribe his name,
"Fearing your hate, O let not hate deſcend,
"Nor make you cruell to ſo vow'd a friend,
"If youle not promiſe loue, grant but acceſſe,
"And let me know my woes are paſt redreſſe,
"Be iuſt then beautious Iudge, and like the lawes
"Condemne me not till you haue heard my cauſe,
"Which when you haue, from thoſe faire lips returne
"Either my life in loue, or death in ſcorne.

sp.l: Am I awake or dreame I, is it true
Or does my flattering fancy but ſuggeſt
What I moſt couet.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Madame the words are there,
Ile ſweare it canna be, nor be illuſion.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: It is too good for truth.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mocke me not fortune,
She kiſt it, ſaweſt thou her, by heauen ſhe kiſt it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And with a looke that reliſht loue, not ſcorne,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: This Letter may be forged, I much deſire to know the certainty, Pſecas thy helpe muſt further me.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.p: Ile not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Here comes my father, he muſt not ſee this.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.p: No nor your tother ſweet heart, hee is with him yonder.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay noble Count you are too old a Souldier
To take a maides firſt no, for a deniall,
They will be nice at firſt, men muſt purſue
That will obtaine, woe her my Lord and take her,
You haue my free conſent if you can get hers,
Yonder ſhe walkes alone, goe comfort her.

sp.speaker: Virro
sp.l: Ile doe the beſt I may, but we old men
Are but cold comfort, I thanke your Lordſhips loue.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I wonder Roſcio that the peeuiſh Girle
Comes on ſo ſlowly on peſwaſions
That I can vſe, do mooue the ſetting forth
Count Ʋirroes greatneſſe, wealth and dignity
Seemes not to affect her, Roſcio.

sp.speaker: Roſcio.
sp.l: I doubt the cauſe my Lord,
For were not that, I dare ingage my life,
She would be wonne to loue him, ſhe has plac'd
Already her affections on ſome other.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: How ſhould I find it out

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Why thus my Lord
Theres neuer man nor woman that ere loued,
But choſe ſome boſome friend whoſe cloſe conuerſe,
Sweeten their ioyes, and eaſe their burdened minds
Of ſuch a working ſecret, thus no doubt
Has my yong Lady done, and but her woman,
Who ſhould it be, tis ſhe muſt out with it,
Her ſecrecy if wit cannot orereach,
Gold ſhall corrupt, leaue that to me my Lord,
But if her Ladies heart doe yet ſtand free
And vnbequeath'd to any, your command
And fathers iuriſdiction enterpos'd
Will make her loue the Count, no kind of m •• ne •
muſt want to draw her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art my Oracle,
My Braine, my Soule, my very being Roſcio,
Walke on and ſpeede whilſt I but ſecond thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is euen ſo, Count Ʋirro is your riuall,
See how the old Ape ſmugs vp his mouldy chap •
To ſeize the bit.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: He muſt not if I liue,
But yet her father brings him that has the meanes
That I ſhould euer want.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If he do marry her
Reuenge it nobly, make him a Cuckold boy,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thou ieſts that feeles it not, prithee lets goe,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Stay, Ile not curſe him briefely for thy ſake,
If thou doeſt marry her mayeſt thou be made
A Cuckold without profit, and nere get
An Office by it, nor fauour at the Court,
But may thy large ill gotten treaſury
Be ſpent in her bought luſt, and thine owne gold
Bring thee adulterers, ſo farewell good Count.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord, ther's a Meſſenger within
Deſires acceſſe, has buſineſſe of import,
Which to no eare but yours he muſt impart.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Admit him, now friend, your buſineſſe with me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: If you be the Lord Polimetes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: My Lord, I come from Athens with ſuch newes
As I dare ſay is welcome though vnlooked for,
Your ſonne Eugenio liues whom you ſo long
Thought dead and mourn'd for.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How, liues.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Vpon my life my Lord I ſaw him well
Within theſe few dayes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thankes for thy good newes,
Towards him Roſcio, but now tell me frend
Haſt thou reueal'd this newes to any man
In Syracuſe but me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: To none my Lord,
At euery place where I haue ſtaid in towne,
Enquiring for your Lordſhips houſe, I heard
Theſe tragicke, but falſe newes, the contrary
I ſtill conceald, though knew, intending firſt
Your Lordſhips eare ſhould drinke it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Worthy f • iend.
I now muſt thanke your wiſedome as your loue
In this well carried action, Ile requite it,
Meane time pray vſe my houſe, and ſtill continue your
Silence in this buſineſſe, Roſcio make him welcome, and
Part as little from him as you can for feare.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Thinke it done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pſecas come hither.

sp.l: Be like your ſelfe, let not a cruell doome
Paſſe thoſe faire lips, that neuer were ordain'd
To kill, but to reuiue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Neither my Lord
Lyes in the power to doe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Yes ſweete to me.
Whom your ſcorne kils, and pitty will reuiue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Pitty is ſhew'd to men in miſery.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And ſo am I, if not relieu'd by you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Twere pride in me, my Lord, to thinke it ſo.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I am your beauties captiue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Then my Lord,
What greater gift then freedome can I giue,
Tis that that Captiues moſt deſires, and that
You ſhall command, y'are free from me my Lord,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Your beauty contradicts that freedome Lady.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: come noble Count, I muſt for this time interrupt you
You'le finde time enough within to talke.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.p: Ile wait vpon your Lordſhip. exeunt manet Euge. ſolus.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Thus in diſguiſe I haue diſcouer'd all,
And found the cauſe of my reported death,
Which did at firſt amaze me, but tis well,
Tis to draw on the match betweene my ſiſter
And this rich Count, heauen grant it be content
As well as fortune to her, but I feare
She cannot loue his age, how it ſucceedes
I ſhall perceiue, and whilſt vnknowne I ſtay,
I cannot hurt the proiect, helpe I may. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This will make good worke for you in the ſpirituall
Court, Shallow is a rich man.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: I marry Sir,
Thoſe are the men we looke for, ther's ſomewhat
To be got, the Court has many buſineſſes at this
Time, but they are little worth, a few waiting
Women got with child by Seruingmen or ſo, ſcarce
Worth the citing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do not their Maſters get
Vm with child ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Yes no doubt, but
They haue got a trick to put vm off vpon their
Men, and for a little portion ſaue their
Owne credits; beſides, theſe priuate marriages
Are much out of our way, we cannot know when
There is a fault.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, theſe are no
Starters I warrant you, Shallow ſhall not deny it,
And for the Wench ſhe neede not confeſſe it, ſhe h • s
A marke that will betray her.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: I thanke you
Sir for your good intelligence, I hope tis certaine.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Feare not that, is your citation ready.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I haue it heere.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Well ſtep aſide, and come when I call, I heare vm comming. Exit Sumner.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Set forward there, Franciſco what make you here.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I come to claime my right, Parſon take heede,
Thou art the Author of adultery
If thou conioyne this couple, ſhee's my wife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: you ſaucebox.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Father, I thought ſhe had beene mine, I hope I ſhall not looſe her thus.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Franciſco, dare not to interrupt vs, for I ſweare thou ſhalt endure the lawes extremity
For thy preſumption.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: doe your worſt, I feare not,
I was contracted to her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What witneſſe haue you.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Heauen is my witneſſe, whoſe imperiall eye ſaw our contract.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What an Aſſe is this to talke of contracting, hee that will get a wench, muſt make her bigger as I haue done, and not contract.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Sir, you are abus'd.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Why ſo.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: The wife you goe to marry is with child, and by another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: A good ieſty faith, make me beleeue that.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: How comes this foole poſſeſt, he neuer toucht her I dare ſweare.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No more Franciſco as you will anſwere it,
Parſon ſet forward there.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: ſtay,
If this will not ſuffice, Sumner come forth.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A Sumner, we are all betraid. Enter Sumner.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: God ſaue you all, I think you gueſſe my buſineſſe,
Theſe are to cite to the ſpirituall Court
You maſter Shallow, and you miſtreſſe Luce,
Aske not the cauſe, for tis apparant here,
A carnall copulation, ante matrimonium.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was a barre vnlookt for, ſpitefull Franciſco

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Iniurious Franklin, could the lawes diuine,
Or humane ſuffer, ſuch an impious act,
That thou ſhouldſt take my true and lawfull wife,
And great with child by me, to giue t'another,
Gulling his poore ſimplicity.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Do you meane me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Gallants Farewell, my writ ſhall be obeyd.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Summer it ſhall. exit Summer

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ile take my leaue, theres nothing now for me to do

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Farewell good maſter Parſon. exit Parſon

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Franciſco canſt thou ſay thou euer louedſt my daughter, and wouldſt thou thus diſgrace her openly.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: No, I would win her thus,
And did you hold her credit halfe ſo deare
As I, or her content, you would not thus
Take her from me, and thruſt her againſt her will
On this rich foole.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: You are very bold with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Let me haue newes what happens deareſt Luce.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Elſe let me die. exit Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was your doing Luce, it had beene
Vnpoſſible he ſhould ere haue knowne the time
So truly elſe, but Ile take an order next time
For you babling.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Whats the matter father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We may
Thanke you for it, this was your haſte that will
Now ſhame vs all, you muſt be doing a fore your
Time.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Twas but a tricke of youth father,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: And threrefore now you muſt eene ſtand in a
White ſheete for all to gaze at.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How,
I would be loath to weare a ſurpleſſe now, tis a
Diſgrace the houſe of the Shallowes neuer knew▪

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: All the hope is, officers may be brib'd, and ſo they will, twere a hard world for vs to liue in elſe.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You ſay true father, if twere not for corruption, euery poore raſcall might haue iuſtice as well as one of vs, and that were a ſhame. exeunt Shal. Luce

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was a cunning ſtratagem well layd,
But yet Franciſco th'haſt not won the prize:
What ſhould I do, I muſt not let this cauſe
Proceed to tryall in the open Court,
For then my daughters oath will caſt the child
Vpon Franciſco: no, I haue found a better,
I will before the next Court day prouide
Some needy Parſon, one whoſe pouerty
Shall make him feare no Cannons, he ſhall marry
My daughter to rich Shallow, when tis done
Ou • gold ſhall make a ſilence in the Court. Exit▪

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: I muſt returne your anſwere to my Lady,
He tell her you will come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come,
And ſuch a Angell call, I ſhould forget
All Offices of Nature, all that men
Wiſh in their ſecond thoughts, ere ſuch a duty
Commend my ſeruice to her, and to you
My thankes for this kind Meſſage. exit Pſecas.
I neuer breath'd till now, neuer till now now
Did my life reliſh ſweeteneſſe, breake not heart,
Cracke not yee feeble Miniſters of nature
With inundation of ſuch ſwelling ioy,
To great to beare without expreſſion:
The Lady writes that ſhe has knowne me long
By ſight, and lou'd me, and ſhe ſeemes to thanke
Her ſtarres ſhe loues, and is belou'd againe,
She ſpeake • my very thoughts, by heauen tis ſtrange
And happy when affections thus can meete;
She further writes at ſuch an houre to day,
Her fathers abſence, and all houſehold ſpi • s
Fitly remoou'd, ſhall giue acceſſe to me
Vnmarkt to viſit her, where ſhe alone
Will entertaine diſcourſe and welcome me.
I hope tis truely meant, why ſhould I feare,
But wiſedome bids me feare: fie, fie, tis baſe,
To wrong a creature of that excellence,
With ſuch ſuſpicion I ſhould iniure her,
I will as ſoone ſuſpect an angell falſe,
Treaſon neare lodg'd within ſo faire a breſt,
No, if her hand betray me, I will will runne
On any danger, tis alike to me
To dye, or find her falſe, for on her truth
Hangs my chiefe being, well Ile loſe no time
No not a minute, deareſt loue I come,
To meete my ſweeteſt wiſhes I will flye,
Heauen and my truth, ſheild me from trechery. Exit.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I Cannot credit it, nor thinke that ſhe
Of all the noble youth in Sicilly,
Should make ſo ſtrange a choiſe, that none but he,
None but the ſonne of my vow'd enemy
Muſt be her mate, it ſtrikes me to amaze,
Minion take heede, doe not belie your Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.l: Mercy forſake me if I doe my Lord,
You charg'd me to confeſſe the truth to you,
Which I haue fully done, and preſently
Ile bring you where conceal'd, you ſhall both ſee
Their priuacy and heare their conference.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well I beleeue thee wench, and will reward
Thy truſt in this, goe get thee in againe
And bring me word when Philocles is come,
Sir youle be ſecret to our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: As your owne breaſt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I ſhall reſt thankfull to you:
This ſtranger muſt be ſoothd leſt he marre all.

sp.speaker: Roſc.
sp.p: This was well found out my Lord, you now haue meanes to take your enemie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With bleſt occaſion I will ſo purſue
As childleſſe Euphes ſhall for euer rue.
Riſe in thy blackeſt looke direſt Nemeſis
Aſſiſtant to my purpoſe, helpe m • glut
My thirſty ſoule with blood. This bold yong man
To his raſh loue ſhall ſacrifice his life.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What courſe you intend, to ruine him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why kill him preſently.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Oh no my Lord,
Youle rue that action, thinke not that the Law
Will let ſuch murther ſleepe vnpuniſhed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Should I now let him goe now I haue caught him

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Yes Sir, to catch him faſter, and more ſafely.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How ſhould that be? ſpeake man.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Why thus my Lord;
You know the law ſpeakes death to any man
That ſteales an Heire without her friends conſent,
This muſt he do, his loue will prompt him to it,
For he can neuer hope by your conſent
To marry her, and ſhe tis like will giue
Content, for womens loue is violent,
Then marke their paſſage you ſhall eaſly find
How to ſurpriſe them at your will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art my Oracle deare Roſcio,
Heres Pſecas come againe; how now what newes?

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.p: My Lord they both are comming pleaſe you withdraw, you ſhall both heare and ſee what you deſire.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye are welcom Noble Sir and did my power,
Anſwere my loue your viſitation,
Sould be more free, and your deſerued welcome
Expreſt in better faſhion.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Beſt of Ladies,
It is ſo well, ſo excellently well,
Comming from your wiſht loue, my barren thanke •
Wants language for't, there lies in your faire lookes
More entertainement then in all the pompe
That the vaine Perſian euer taught the world,
Your preſence is the welcome I expected,
That makes it perfect.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Tis your noble thought
Makes good whats wanting here, but gentle friend,
For ſo I now dare call you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Tis well Minion you are bold
Enough I ſee to chuſe your friends without my leaue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tis my ambition euer to be yours.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Thinke me not light, deare Philocles, ſo ſoone
To grant thee loue, that others might haue ſought
With eagereſt purſuit, and not obtain'd,
But I was yours by fate, and long haue beene,
Before you wood Leucothoe was wonne,
And yours without reſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh my Starres
Twas your kind influence, that whiſt I ſlept
In dulleſt ignorance, contriu'd for me
The way to crowne me with felicity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You may be deceiu'd though,
You haue no ſuch great reaſon
To thanke your Starres if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And know faire Miſtreſſe you haue met a loue,
That time, nor fate, nor death can euer change,
A man that but in you can haue no being:
Let this kiſſe ſeale my faith.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And this mine.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay too't againe, your ſweete meate ſhall haue ſowre ſawce.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But ſweet, 'mongſt all theſe Roſes ther's one thorne
That prickes and galls me, our parents enmity
Will croſſe our loues, I doe aſſure my ſonne
This father neuer will giue his conſent.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No ſo I thinke, he moues me ſtill to Virro
That old craz'd Count, and with ſuch vehemency
I dare ſcarce bide his preſence if I deny him;
Therefore we muſt be ſpeedy in our courſe,
And take without his leaue what he denyes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thanke you for that good daughter.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I told you Sir twould come to this at laſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh thou haſt ſpoke my wiſhes, and hath ſhewd
Thy ſelfe in loue as true as beautifull;
Then let's away deareſt Leucothoe,
My fortunes are not poore, then feare no want,
This conſtant loue of ours may proue ſo happy,
To reconcile our parents enmity.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Heauen grant it may.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Neuer by this meanes yongſter.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: But ſoft now I thinke better ont Ile not goe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why deareſt, is thy loue ſo quickly cold?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No, but ile not venter thee, thine is the danger,
Thou knoweſt tis death by law to ſteale an heire,
And my deare brothers moſt vntimely death,
Hath lately made me one, what if thou ſhouldſt be taken.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh feare not that, had I a thouſand liues,
They were too ſmall a venture for ſuch priſe,
I tell thee ſweete, a face not halfe ſo faire
As thine, hath arm'd whole actions in the field,
And brought a thouſand ſhips to Tenedos,
To ſacke lamented Troy, and ſhould I feare
To venture one poore life, and ſuch a life
As would be loſt in nor poſſeſſing thee:
Come come, make that no ſcruple, when ſhall we goe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This preſent euening, for to morrow morning
My father lookes that I ſhould giue conſent
To marry with the Count,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beſt of all, would twere this preſent houre,
Ile goe prepare, but ſhall I call thee heere.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Oh no, weele meete.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Where deareſt.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Eaſt from the City by a Riuers ſide,
Not diſtant halfe a mile there ſtands a groue,
Where often riding by I haue obſerued
A little Hermitage, there I will ſtay
If I be firſt, if you, doe you the like,
Let th'houre be ten, then ſhall I beſt eſcape.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nere ſweeter comfort came from Angels lips
I know the place, and will be ready there
Before the houre: Ile bring a friend with me
As true as mine owne heart, one Clerimont,
That may doe vs good if danger happen.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Vſe your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Deareſt farewell,
Houres will ſeeme yeeres till we are met againe. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ah Sirrah, this geere goes well, god a mercy girle
For thy intelligence, why this is as much as a
Man could deſire, the time, place, and euery thing;
I warrant vm they paſſe no further, well
Goe thou in and wait vpon thy Miſtreſſe, ſhees
Melancholly till ſhe ſee her ſweete heart againe, but
When ſhee does, ſhee ſhall not ſee him long,
Not a word of whats paſt among vs for your life.

sp.speaker: Pſe.
sp.p: I warrant you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ile not ſo much as ſhew an angry looke,
Or any token that I know any of their proceedings,
But Roſio, we muſt lay the place ſtrongly, if they
Should ſcape vs, I were pritily fool'd now after all
This.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Why tis impoſſible my Lord, weele goe
Strong enough, beſides I thinke it fit we tooke
An Officer along with vs to countenance it the
Better.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou ſayſt well, goe get one,
Ile goe my ſelfe along with you too, I loue
To ſee ſport though I am old, you'le goe
Along with vs to Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I Sir, you ſhall
Command my ſeruice when you are ready.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now Euphues, what I did but barely act
Thy bleeding heart ſhall feele, loſſe of a ſonne
If Law can haue his courſe, as who can let it,
I know thou think'ſt mine dead, and in thy heart
Laugheſt at my falling houſe, but let them laugh
That winne the prize, things nere are knowne till ended.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well I like my ſiſters choiſe, ſhe has taken a man
Whoſe very lookes and carriage ſpeake him
Worthy, beſides he is Noble, his fortunes ſufficient,
They both loue each other, what can my father
More deſire, that he gapes ſo after this old
Count▪ that comes for the eſtate, as tother vpon
My ſoule does not, but pure ſpotleſſe loue, but
Now his plot is for reuenge vpon his old enemy:
Fye, Fye tis bloudy and vnchriſtian, my ſoule
Abhors ſuch acts, this match may rather
Reconcile our houſes, and I deſire where worth
Is to haue friendſhip, as on my ſoule tis there.
Well Philocles I hope to call thee brother.
Somewhat Ile doe, Ile goe perſwade Count Ʋirro
Not to loue her, I know the way, and Ile but
Tell him truth her brother liues, that will
Coole his loue quickly; but ſoft, here comes
The Count as fit as may be.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: She loues me not yet, but that's no matter,
I ſhall haue her, her father ſayes I ſhall,
And I dare take his word, maides are quickly
Ouer-rul'd, ah, ah, me thinkes I am growne yonger
Then I was by twenty yeeres, this Fortune
Caſt vpon me, is better then Medeas charme, to
Make an old man yong againe, to haue a
Lords eſtate freely beſtowed, and with it ſuch
A beauty as ſhould warme Nectors bloud,
Make old Priam luſty. Fortune I ſee thou loueſt me
Now, Ile build a Temple to thee ſhortly, and
Adore thee as the greateſt deity. Now what are you.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: A poore Scholler my Lord, one that
Am little beholding to Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: So are moſt of your profeſſion,
Thou ſhouldſt t • ke ſome more thriuing
Occupation, to be a iudges man, they are
The braueſt now adayes, or a Cardinals
Pander, that were • good profeſſion and gainefull.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: But not lawfull, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ʋerro.
sp.l: Lawfull,
That Cardinall may come to be Pope, and
Then he could pardon thee and himſelfe too.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My Lord I was brought vp a Scholler.
And I thanke your counſell, My
Lord, I haue ſome for you, and therefore I
Came.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: For me, what I prithee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Tis weighty and concernes you neere.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Speake, what iſt?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: My Lord, you are to marry old Polimetes Daughter.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And Heire.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: No Heire
My Lord, her Brother is aliue.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: How, Thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My Lord,
What I ſpeake is true, and to my knowledge
His father giues it out in pollicy to marry his
Daughter the better, to hooke in ſutors, and
Specially aym'd at you, thinking you rich
And couetous, and now he has caught you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: But doſt thou mock me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Let me be euer miſerable if I ſpeake
Not truth, as ſure as I am here Eugenio liues,
I know it, and know him, where he is.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Where prithee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Not a daies iourney hence,
Where his father enioyn'd him to ſtay till your
Match, and ſends word to him of this plot:
Beſides, I ouer-hard the old Lord and his man
Roſcio, laughing at you for being caught thus.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why, wert thou at the houſe then.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Yes, But had ſcuruy entertainment
Which I haue thus reueng'd

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Beſhrew my heart I know not what
To thinke on't, til like enough, this Lord was
Alwayes cunning beyond meaſure, and it
Amaz'd me that he ſhould grow ſo exreme
Kind to me on the ſuddaine to offer me all this:
Beſides this fellow is ſo confident, and on
No ends of couznage that I can ſee; well,
I would faine enioy her, the Wench is
Delicate, but I would haue the eſtate too, and
not be guld, what ſhall I doe, now braines
If euer you will, helpe your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It ſtings him.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Well, ſo, Sir,
What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Irus my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Your name as well as your attire
Speakers you poore.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I am ſo.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: And very poore.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Very poore.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Would you not gladly take a courſe
To get money, and a great ſome of mony.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is gladly if your Lordſhip would but
Shew me the way.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Harke ye.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Fye, neuer
Talke of the Conſcience, and for Law thou art
Free, for all men thinke him dead, and
His father will be aſhamed to follow it
Hauing already giuen him for dead,
And then who can know it, come be wiſe,
Fiue hundreth crownes Ile giue.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Well, tis pouerty that does it, and not I,
When ſhall I be paid.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: When thou haſt done it.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Well giue me your
Hand for it my Lord

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In writing, to be paid when I haue
Poyſoned him, and thinke it done.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Now thou
But loue has made me bold, the time has beene,
In ſuch a place as this I ſhould haue fear'd
Each rowling leafe, and trembled at a reed
Stird in the Mooneſhine, my fearefull fancy
Would frame a thouſand appariſions,
And worke ſome feare out of my very ſhadow:
I wonder Philocles is tardy thus,
When laſt wee parted euery houre, he ſaid,
Would ſeeme a yeere till we were met againe,
It ſhould not ſeeme ſo by the haſt he makes
Ile ſit and reſt me, come I know he will.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This Clerimont this is the happy place
Where I ſhall meet the ſumme of all my ioyes,
And be poſſeſt of ſuch a treaſury
As would inrich a Monarch.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This is his voyce,
My Philocles.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My life, my ſoule, what here before me,
Oh thou doſt ſtill out goe me, and doſt make
All my endeauours poore in the requitall
Of thy large fauours, but I forget my ſelfe.
Sweete bid my friend here welcome, this is he
That I dare truſt next mine owne hearth with ſecrets.
But why art thou diſguiſed thus.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I durſt not venture elſe to make eſcape.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Euen now me thinkes I ſtand as I would wiſh
With all my wealth about me, ſuch a loue
And ſuch a friend, what can be added more
To make a man liue happy, thou darke groue
That haſt beene cald the ſeat of Melancholy,
And ſhelter for the diſcontented ſpirits;
Sure thou art wrong, thou ſeemſt to me a place
Of ſolace and content, a Paradiſe
That giueſt me more then euer Court could doe
Or richeſt Palace, bleſt be thy faire ſhades,
Let birds of muſicke euer chant it heere,
No croking Rauen, or ill booding Owle
Make heere their balefull hahitation
Frighting thy walkes, but mayſt thou be a groue
Where loues faire Queene may take delight to ſport:
For vnder thee two faithfull Louers meet,
Why is my faire Leucothoe ſo ſad.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I know no cauſe, but I would faine be gone.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Whether ſweete.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Any whether from hen • e.
My thoughts diuine of treaſon, whence I know not,
There is no creature knowes our meeting heere
But one, and thats my maid, ſhe has beene truſty
And will be ſtill I hope, but yet I would
She did not know it, prithee lets away
Any where elſe, we are ſecure from danger.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then lets remoue, but prithee be not ſad.
What noiſe is that.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Oh feare not Loue. draw.

div.stage: Eer Polimedes, Roſcio, Eugenio and Officers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Vpon vm Officers, yonder they are.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Theeues, Villaines.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art the Thiefe and the Villaine too,
Giue me my Daughter thou rauiſher.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Firſt take my life.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Vpon vm I ſay. fight.
Knocke vm downe Officers if they reſiſt, they are taken.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Oh they are loſt, ah wicked, wicked Pſecas;

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
So keepe vm faſt, weele haue vm faſter ſhortly, and for you Minion, Ile tye a clog about your neck for running
away any more.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Yet do but heare me father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Call me not father thou diſobedient wretch,
Thou Run-away, thou art no child of mine,
My Daughter nere wore Breeches.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Oh Sir, my Mother would haue done as much
For loue of you, if need had ſo required,
Thinke not my mind transformed as my habite.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Officers away with vm, peace Stumpet,
You may diſcharge him, he's but an aſſiſtant.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Oh ſtay and heare me yet, heare but a word
And that my laſt it may be, doe not ſpill
The life of him in whom my life ſubſiſts,
Kill not two liues in one, remember Sir,
I was your Daughter once, once you did loue me,
And tell me then, what fault can be ſo great,
To make a father murtherer of his child,
For ſo you are in taking of his life.
Oh thinke not Sir that I will ſtay behinde him
Whilſt there be Aſpes, and Kniues, and burning Coles▪
No Roman dame ſhall in her great example
Outgoe my loue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh where will ſorrow ſtay,
Is there no end in griefe or in my death
Not puniſhment enough for my offence,
But muſt her griefe be added to afflict me;
Dry vp thoſe Pearles deareſt Leucothoe,
Or thou wilt make me doubly miſerable,
Preſerue that life, that I may after death
Liue in my better part, take comfort deare,
People would curſe me, if ſuch beauty ſhould
For me miſcarry, no, liue happy thou,
And let me ſuffer what the law inflicts.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: My offence was as great as thine,
And why ſhould not my puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come haue you done, Officers away with him.
Ile be your keeper, but Ile looke better to you.
But Roſie you and I muſt about the buſineſſe:
sir let it be your charge to watch my Daughter,
And ſee ſhe ſend no meſſage any whither,
Nor receiue any.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It ſhall my Lord. exeunt manet Eu. and Leu.
Ile be an Argus, none ſhall come heere I warrant you,
My very heart bleedes to ſee two ſuch louers ſo
Faithfully parted ſo. I muſt condemne my father,
Hees too cruell in this hard action, and did not
Nature forbid it, I could raile at him, to reake
His long foſtred malice againſt Lord Euphues thus
Vpon his ſonne, the faithfull louer of his owne
Daughter, and vpon her, for ſhould it come to paſſe
As he expects it ſhall, I thinke t' would kill her
Too, ſhe takes it —: See in what ſtrange amazement
Now ſhe ſtands, her griefe has ſpent it ſelfe ſo
Farre that it has left her ſenceleſſe, it greeues
Me thus to ſee her, I can ſcarce forbeare reuealing
Of my ſelfe to her, but that I keepe it for a
Better occaſion when things ſhall better anſwere to
My purpoſe: Lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What are you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In that my Lord your father has appointed
To giue attendance on you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: On me, alas I neede no attendance,
He might beſtow his care better for me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I came but lately to him, nor doe I meane
Long to ſtay with him, in the meane time Lady
Might I but doe you any ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: All ſeruice is too late, my hopes are deſeperate.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Madame, I haue a feeling of your woe,
A greater your owne brother could not haue,
And thinke not that I come ſuborn'd by any
To vndermine your ſecrets, I am true,
By all the gods I am, for further tryall
Command me any thing, ſend me on any meſſage
Ile doe it faithfully, or any thing elſe
That my poore power can compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Oh ſtrange fate
Haue I loſt pitty in a fathers heart,
And ſhall I find it in a ſtranger: Sir
I ſhall not liue to thanke you, but my prayers
Shall goe with you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Tis not for thankes or neede
But for the ſeruice that I owe to vertue
I would doe this.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Surely this man
Is nobly bred, how ere his habite giue him:
But Sir, all phyſicke comes to me too late,
There is no hope my Philocles ſhould liue▪

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Vnleſſe the King were pleaſd to grant his pardon,
Twe're good that he were mou'd.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ah who ſhould doe it,
I feare me tis in vaine, Count Virro
And my father both will croſſe it, but I would venture
If I could get but thither.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Thats in my power
To giue you liberty, your father left me
To be your keeper, but in an act
So meritorious as this, I will not hinder you,
Nay I will waite vpon you to the Court.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A thouſand thankes to you, well ile goe,
Grant oh you powers aboue, if Virgins teares,
If a true loues prayers had euer power
To moue compaſſion grant it now to me,
Arm'd with ſo ſtrong a vigor, my weake words
They may pierce deepe into his kingly breſt,
And force out mercy in ſpite of all oppoſers.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Come lets away. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: MY deareſt Luce, were thy old Sire as iuſt
As thou art truely conſtant, our firme loue
Had neuer met theſe oppoſitions,
All my deſignes as yet, all practiſes
That I haue vs'd, I ſee are fruſtrated,
For as my faire intelligencer writes,
He will before the next court day prouide
Some careleſſe perſon▪ that in ſpite of lawes
Shall marry her to Shallow, this being done,
He meanes to hold the Cou • ts ſeuerity
To by a golden bit, and ſo he may,
Al •• it is too true, I muſt preuent it,
And that in time, before it grow too farre;
But how, there lies the point of difficulty:
But what ſtrange ſight is this that greetes mine eyes,
Alphonſo my old Captaine, ſure tis he.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thus once againe from twenty yeares exile,
Toſt by the ſtormes of fortune too and fro,
Has gratious heauen giuen me leaue to tread
My natiue earth of Sicily and draw
That aire that fed me in my infancy.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Tis he, moſt noble Captaine, oh what power
Has bene ſo gratious as to bleſſe mine eyes
Once more with ſight of my moſt honored maſter.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Kind y • uth the teares of ioy that I haue ſpent
To greet my natiue country haue quite robd
Mine eyes of moyſture, and haue left me none
To anſwer thy affection, but tell me,
Tell me how thou haſt liu'd in Syracuſe
Theſe fiue yeeres here, ſince that vnluckly ſtorme
Diuided vs at Sea.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Faith poorely Sir,
As one that knows no kindred nor alliance,
Vnknowne of any haue I ſhifted out,
But I haue heard you ſay that I was borne
In Syracuſe, tell me what ſtocke I come of,
What parentage, how meane ſo ere they be,
They canno • well be poorer then my ſelfe,
Speake, do you know them Sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes very well,
And I am glad the fates haue brought me home,
For thy deare ſake, that I may now diſcloſe
Thy honorable birth.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Honorable?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes noble youth, thou art the ſecond ſonne
To old Lord Euphues, a man more worthy
And truly noble neuer drew this ayre;
Thy name's Lyſandro, this diſcouery
Will be as welcome to your friends as you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: You do amaze me Sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ile tell you all,
It was my fortune, twenty a yeare ago,
Vpon the Tyrrhene ſhore, whoſe ſea diuides
This Ile from Italy, to keepe a fort
Vnder your noble father, where your ſelfe
Then but a child, was left to my tuition,
When ſodainly the rude aſſailing force
Of ſtrong Italian Pirats ſo preuaild,
As to ſurpriſall of the fort and vs.
Your name and noble birth I then conceald,
Fearing ſome outrage from the enmity
Of thoſe fell Pyrates, and ſince from your ſelfe
I purpoſely haue kept the knowlenge of it.
As loath to grieue your preſent miſery
With knowledge of what fortunes you had loſt,
That this is true, you ſtraight ſhall ſee th'effect,
Ile goe acquaint your father with the tokens,
And make his oreioyde heart leape to embrace
Thee his new found and long forgotten ſonne:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Worthy Captaine, your preſence was alwayes
Welcome to me, but this vnlookt for newes, I
Cannot ſuddenly diſgeſt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well Ile go to him preſently. exit Alphonſo.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now my deare Luce, I ſhall finde meanes to quite
Thy loue, that couldſt deſcend ſo low as I
When I was nothing, and with ſuch affection,
This was my ſuit ſtill to the powers aboue,
To make me worthy of thy conſtant loue.
Exit Franciſco. But ile about the proiect I intended.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why now my Lord you are neerer to her loue then euer you were yet, your riuall by this accident ſhall be remoued out of the way, for before the ſcorneful girle would neuer fancy any man elſe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I conceiue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I labourd it for your ſake as much as for my
Owne, to remoue your riuall and my enemy, you
Haue your loue, and I haue my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I ſhall liue my Lord to giue you thankes, but aſide.
T'will be after a ſtrange manner, if Irus has
Diſpatched what he was hired too, then my kind
Lord I ſhall be a little too cunning for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Lord you are gracious with the King.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.p: I thanke his Maieſty, I haue his care before another man.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then ſee no pardon be granted, you may ſtop any thing; I knew Euphues will be ſoliciting for his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I warrant you my Lord no pardon paſſes whilſt I am there, ile bee a barre betwixt him and the King, but hearke the King approaches.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Health to your Maieſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Count Virro, and Lord Polimetes welcome,
You haue beene ſtrangers at the Court of late;
But I can well excuſe you Count, you are about a wife,
A yong one and a faire one too they ſay,
Get me yong ſouldiers Count, but ſpeake
When is the day, I meane to be your gueſt,
You ſhall not ſteale a martiage.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.p: I thanke your Maieſty, but the marriage that I intended is ſtolen to my hand, and by another.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Stolne, how man.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My promiſed wife
Is lately ſtolne away by Philocles,
Lord Euphues ſonne againſt her fathers will,
Who followed vm and apprehended them,
The Law may right vs Sir, if it may haue courſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No reaſon but the law ſhould haue his courſe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Pardon dread Soueraigne, pardon for my ſonne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Your ſonne, Lord Euphues, what is his offence.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: No hainous one my Leige, no plot of treaſon
Againſt your royall perſon or your ſtate,
Theſe aged cheekes would bluſh to beg a pardon
For ſuch a foule offence, no crying murder
Hath ſteyned his innocent hands, his fault was loue,
Loue my deare Leige, vnfortunately he tooke
The Daughter and Heire of Lord Polimetes,
Who followes him and ſeekes exſtremity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I ſeeke but Law, I am abus'd my Leige,
Iuſtice is all I beg, my Daughters ſtolne,
Staffe of my age, let the law doe me right,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To his iuſt prayers doe I bend my knee
My promiſed wife is ſtolne, and by the ſonne
Of that iniurious Lord, iuſtice I craue.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Be like thoſe powers aboue, whoſe place on earth
You repreſent, ſhew mercy gracious King,
For they are mercifull.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Mercy is but the Kings prerogatiue,
Tis Iuſtice is his office, doing that
He can wrong no man, no man can complaine,
But mercy ſhewed oft takes way reliefe
From the wronged partie that the Law would giue him:

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: The Law is blind and ſpeakes in generall termes,
She cannot pitty where occaſion ſerues,
The liuing law can moderate her rigour,
And thats the King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The King I hope in this will not do ſo,

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Tis malice makes thee ſpeake,
Hard hearted Lord, hadſt thou no other way
To wreake thy cankred and long foſtred hate
Vpon my he • d but thus, thus bloudily
By my ſonnes ſuffering, and for ſuch a fault
As thou ſhouldſt loue him rather, is thy daughter
Diſparaged by his loue, is his blood baſe,
Or are his fortunes ſunke, this law was made
For ſuch like cautions, to reſtraine the baſe
From wronging noble perſons by attempts
Of ſuch a kind, but where equality
Meetes in the match, the fault is pardonable.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Mercy my Soueraigne, mercy gratious King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Minion who ſent for you, twere more modeſty
For you to be at home.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let her alone, ſpeake Lady,
I charge you no man interupt her. Enter Leucothoe

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: If euer pitty toucht that princely breſt,
If euer Virgins teares had power to moue,
Or if you euer lou'd and felt the pangs
That other louers doe, pitty great King,
Pitty and pardon two vnhappy Louers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Your life is not in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Yes royall Sir
If Law condemne my Philocles, he and I
Haue but one heart, and can haue but one fate.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Excellent vertue thou hadſt not this from thy father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ther's Muſicke in her voice, and in her face
More then a mortall beauty▪ Oh my heart,
I ſhall be loſt in paſſion if I heare her,
Ile heere no more, conuey her from my preſence,
Quickly I ſay.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: This is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I told you what he would doe, I knew
He would not here of a pardon, and I againſt it,
He reſpects me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No doubt he does my Lord▪
I like this paſſage well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But ſtay,
Stay Lady, let me heare you, beſhrew my heart
My minde was running of another matter.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Where the diuell hath his minde bin all this while,
Perhaps he heard none of vs neither,
We may eene tell our tales againe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No ſure he heard vs, but tis very ſtrange.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis ſuch a tempting poiſon I draw in,
I cannot ſtay my draught, riſe vp Lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Neuer vntill your graces pardon raiſe me,
Ther's pitty in your eye, oh ſhew it Sir,
Say Pardon gracious King, tis but a word
And ſhort, but welcome as the breath of life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ile further here the manner of this fact,
Auoid the preſence all, all but the Lady,
And come not till I ſend.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I like not this.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.p: Nor I here is mad dancing.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Heauen bleſſe thy ſute thou mirror of thy ſex,
And beſt example of true conſtant loue,
That in the Sea of thy tranſcendent vertues
Drown'ſt all thy fathers malice, and redeem'ſt
More in my thoughts then all thy kin can loſe. exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now Lady what would you doe to ſaue the life
Of him you loue ſo deerely.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I cannot thinke that thought I would not doe,
Lay it in my power, and beyond my power
I would attempt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You would be thankefull then
To me if I ſhould grant his pardon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: If euer I were thankefull to the gods
For all that I call mine, my health and being,
Could I to you be vnthankefull for a gift
I value more then thoſe, without which
Theſe bleſſings were but weariſome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thoſe that are thankefull ſtudy to requite
A courteſie, would you doe ſo? would you requite
This fauour▪

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I cannot Sir,
For all the ſeruice I can doe your Grace
Is but my duty, you are my Soueraigne,
And all my deedes to you are debts not merits,
But to thoſe powers aboue that can requite,
That from their vaſtleſſe treaſures hope rewards,
More out of grace then merrit on vs mortals,
To thoſe ile euer pray that they would giue you
More bleſſings then I haue skill to aske.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay but Leucothoe, this lies in thy power to requite, thy loue will make requitall, wilt thou loue me?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I euer did my Lord.
I was inſtructed from my infancy,
To loue and honour you my Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But in a neerer bond of loue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: There is no neerer nor no truer loue
Then that a loyall ſubiect beares a Prince.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Still thou wilt not conceiue me▪ I muſt deale plain
With you, wilt thou lye with me, and I will ſeale his
Pardon preſently; nay more, ile • heape vpon you
Both all fauours, all honours that a Prince can giue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Oh me vnhappy, in what a ſad dilemma ſtands my choiſe.
Either to loſe the man my ſoule moſt loues,
Or ſaue him by a deed of ſuch diſhonour
As he will euer loath me for, and hate
To draw that breath that was ſo baſely kept.
Name any thing but that to ſaue his life,
I know you doe but tempt my frailty Sir,
I know your royall thoughts could neuer ſtoope
• o ſuch a ſoule diſhonourable act.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bethinke your ſelfe, there is no way but that,
I ſweare by Heauen neuer to pardon him
But vpon thoſe conditions.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Oh I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art not if not wilfull, yeeld Leucothoe,
It ſhall be ſecret, Philocles for his life
Shall thanke thy loue, but neuer know the price
Thou paidſt for it; be wiſe thou heardſt me ſweare,
I cannot now ſhew mercy, thou maiſt ſaue him,
And if he dye, tis thou that art the Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ſhould be ſo if I ſhould ſaue him thus,
Nay I ſhould be a Traytor to your grace,
Betray your ſoule to ſuch a foe as luſt,
But ſince your oath is paſt, deare Philocles
Ile ſhew to thee an honeſt cruelty,
And rather follow thee in ſpotleſſe death,
Then buy with ſinning a diſhonoured life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet pitty me Leucothoe, cure the wound
Thine eyes hath made, pitty a begging King,
Vncharme the charmes of thy bewitching face,
Or thou wilt leaue me dead: will nothing moue thee,
Thou art a Witch, a Traytor, thou haſt ſought
By vnreſiſted ſpels thy ſoueraignes life:
Who are about vs there, call in the Lords againe,
Lord Pol ••• tes, take your daughter to you,
Keepe her at home.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will my Leige, Roſio ſee her there I wonder what is done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Euphues I haue tane a ſolemne oath
Neuer to grant a pardon to thy ſ • nne.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: O ſay not ſo my Leige, your grace I know
Has mercy for a greater fault then this.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My oath is paſt and cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: This is beyond our wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: What made him ſweare this I wonder.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: A heauy oath to me and moſt vnlooked for,
Your iuſtice Sir has ſet the period
Vnto a loyall houſe, a Family
That haue bin props of the Sicylian crowne,
That with their blouds in many an honourd field,
Gainſt the hot French, and Neopolitan
Haue ſeru'd for you and your great Anceſtors,
Their children now can neuer more doe ſo,
Farewell my Soueraigne, whileſt I in teares
Spend the ſ • d rem • an • of my childleſſe age,
Ile pray for your long life and happy raigne,
And may your Grace and your Poſterity
At neede finde hands as good and hearts as true
As ours haue euer beene.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Farewell good old man.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: For you my Lord, your cruelty has deſeru'd
A c • rſe from me, but I can vtter none,
Your Daughters goodneſſe has weigh'd down your malice
Heauen proſper her.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He is an honeſt man and truely noble,
Oh my raſh oath, my luſt, that was the cauſe,
Would any price would buy it in againe.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Your Maieſty is iuſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Tis a happy Land
Where the King ſquares his actions by the law.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, you are baſe and bloudy,
That feedes your malice with pretence of iuſtice,
Tis ſuch as you make Princes tirranous,
And hated of their ſubiects, but looke too't,
