Looke your owne heads ſtands faſt for if the law
Doe finde a hole in your coates, beg no mercy.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Pardon vs my Lord, we were wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And ſought redreſſe but by a lawfull courſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well leaue me alone.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Fare well my Leige, now let him chafe alone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Now we haue our ends. exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is there no meanes to ſaue him no way,
To g •• a diſpenſation for an oath,
〈◊〉 that I know except the Court of Rome
Will grant one, thats well thought on,
I will not ſpare for gold, and that will doe it,

sp.speaker: Nica.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What booke is that
Thou hadſt from Paris about the price of ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Tis cald the Texes of the Apoſtolicall Chancery.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Is there a price for any ſinne ſet downe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: A my Sir, how heinous ere it be,
Or of what nature, for ſuch a ſumme of money
As is ſet downe there, it ſhall be remitted

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Thats well, go fetch the book preſently. exit Nic.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sure there is periury
Among the reſt, and I ſhall know what rate
It beares before I haue committed it.
How now haſt brought it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Reade, I would know the price of periury,

sp.speaker: Nic
sp.p: I ſhall find it quickly, heres an Index. he reads Imp. For murder of all kinds of a Clergy man, of a lay man, of father, mother, Sonne, brother, ſiſter, wife.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Reade till you come at periury.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Item, for impoyſoning, enchantments, witchcraft,
Sacriledge, ſimony, and their kind and
Branches. Item, pro lapſu carnis, fornication
Adultery, inceſt without any exception or
Diſtinction; for ſodomy, Brutality, or any of
That kind.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My heart ſhakes with horror
To heare the names of ſuch deteſted ſinnes,
Can theſe be bought for any price of money,
Or do theſe merchants but deceiue the world
With their falſe Wares▪ no more of that foule booke,
I will know what I came to know,
I would not for the world redeeme my oath
By ſuch a c • urſe as this, no more Nicanor
Vnleſſe thou finde a price for Atheiſme.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Heres none for that my Lord, his Holineſſe
Can pardon that in no man but himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well this is not the way,
I haue thought of another that may proue,
And both diſcharge my oath and ſaue his life,
Nicanor run preſently, call Matho hither,
Matho the Lawyer, command him to make haſt,
I long to be reſolued.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I runne Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He is a ſubtill Lawyer, and may find
Some point, that in the Lawes obſcurity
• ee hid from vs, ſome point may doe vs good,
I haue ſeene ſome of his profeſſion
Out of caſe as plaine, as cleere as day
To our weake iudgements, and no doubt at firſt
Meant like our thoughts by thoſe that made the Law,
Picke out ſuch hard inextricable doubts,
That they haue ſpun a ſuit of ſeuen yeere long,
And leade their hood winke Clients in a wood,
A moſt irremoueable Labyrinth,
Till they haue quite conſum'd vm, this they can doe
In other caſes, why not as well in this.
I haue ſeene others could extend the Law
Vpon the wrack, or cut it ſhort againe
To their owne priuate profits, as that thiefe
Cruell Procruſtes ſeru'd his hapleſſe gueſts,
To fi • them to his bed; Well I ſhall ſee,
I would Nicanor were returned againe,
I would faine eaſe my conſcience of that oath,
That raſh and inconſiderate oath I tooke,
But ſee, heere they are comming. Enter Matho.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Health to my Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Matho, welcome.
I ſent for thee about a buſineſſe
I would intreate thy helpe in.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your Highneſſe may command my ſeruice
In that, or any thing lies in my power.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Tis to decide a caſe that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If it lye within the compaſſe of my knowledge,
I will reſolue your Highneſſe preſently.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then thus it is, Lord Euphues ſonne,
Yong Philocles, has lately ſtolne away
The Daughter and Heire of Lord Polimetes,
Who is his enemy, he following him hard
Has apprehended him, and brings him to his tryall
To morrow morning: thou haſt heard this newes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I haue my Liege, and euery circumſtance
That can be thought on in the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And what will be the iſſue by the Law.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He muſt dye for it, the caſe is plaine,
Vnleſſe your grace will grant his pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But can there be no meanes thought vpon
To ſaue him by the Law.

sp.speaker: Matho.
sp.p: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Surely there may, ſpeake man, Ile giue thee
Double Fees.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It cannot be my Leige, the Statutes is plaine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay now thou art too honeſt, thou ſhouldſt do
As other Lawyers doe, firſt take my mony,
And then tell me thou canſt doe me good.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I dare not vndertake it, could it be done,
Ide goe as farre as any man would doe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes if twere to cut a poore mans throat you could,
For ſome rich griping Land-lord you could grin'd
The face of his poore Tenant, ſtretch the Law
To ſerue his turne, and guided by his Angels,
Speake Oracles more then the tongues of men,
Then you could find exceptions, reſeruations,
Stand at a word, a ſilible, a letter,
Or coine ſome ſcruples out of your owne braines,
But in a cauſe ſo full of equity
So charitable as this, you can find nothing,
I ſhall for euer hate all your profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I do beſeech your Highneſſe to excuſe me,
I cannot doe more then your lawes will let me,
Nor falſifie my knowledge nor my conſcience.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then I am miſerable, riſe Matho riſe,
I do not diſcommend thy honeſty,
But blame my owne hard fate, ay Philocles
I would redeeme thy life at any price,
But the Starres croſſe it, cruell fate condemnes thee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come fellow watchmen, for now you are my fellowes,

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: I • pleaſes you to call vs ſo maſter Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I do it to encourage you in your office, it is a tricke that we commanders haue, your great Captains call your ſouldiers fellow ſouldiers to encourage them.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p: Indeed and ſo they do, I heard maſter Curate trading a ſtory booke tother day to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well I muſt ſhew now what you haue to do, for I my ſelfe before I came to this prefermity, was as ſimple as one of you, and for your better deſtruction, I will deride my ſpeech into two parts. Firſt, what is a watchman. Secondly, what is the office of a watchman. For the firſt, fany man aske me what is a watchman, I may anſwer him, he is a man as others are, nay a tradeſman, as a Vintner, a Tayler, or the like, for they haue long bils.

sp.speaker: • . Wat.
sp.p: He tels vs true neighbour, we haue bils indeed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: For the ſecond, what is his office; I anſwer, he may by vertue of his office reprehend any perſon, or perſons, that w • lke the ſtreets too late at a ſeaſonable houre.

sp.speaker: 4. Wat
sp.p: may we indeed maſter Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nay, if you meet any of thoſe rogues at ſeaſonable houres, you may by vertue of your office commit him to priſon, and then aske him whither he was going.

sp.speaker: • . Watch.
sp.p: Why thats as much as my Lord Maior does.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: True, my Lord Maior can doe no more then you in that point.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: But maſter conſtable what if hee ſhould reſiſt vs.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Why if he do reſiſt, you may knocke him downe, and then • id him ſtand, and come afore the Conſtable. So 〈…〉 you are ſufficiently cnſtructed concerning you office take your ſtands, you ſhall heare rogues walking at theſe ſeaſonable houres, I warrant you, ſtand cloſe.

sp.l: Purpoſe, now doe I take as much care to be apprehended,
As others doe to ſcape the watch, I muſt ſpeake
To be ouerheard, and plainly too, or els theſe dolts
Will neuer conceiue mee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Harke who goes by?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Oh my conſcience, my conſcience, the teror of a Guilty conſcience.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How, conſcience talkes hee of,
He's an honeſt man, I warant him, let him paſſe

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: I I, let him paſſe, good night honeſt gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Theſe are wiſe officers, I muſt bee plainer yet.
That gold, that curſed gold, that made me poiſon him
Made me poiſon Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: How made me poiſon him, he's a knaue I warrant him.

sp.speaker: 3. Wa.
sp.l: M. Conſtable has found him already,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I warant you a knaue cannot paſſe me, go reprehend him, Ile take his excommunication my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.l: Come afore the conſtable

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: Come afore the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sirrah, ſirrah, you would haue ſcap'd
Would you, no ſirrah you ſhall know the Kings
Officers haue eyes to heare ſuch roagues as you,
Come ſirrah, confeſſe who it was you poiſon'd, he
Lookes like a notable roague.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.l: I dooe not like
His lookes.

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: nor I.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You would deny it
Would you ſirra, we ſhall ſift you,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Alas maſter

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I cannot now deny what I have ſaid
You ouer heard me, I poiſoned Eugenio ſonne to
Lord Polimetes.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.p: Oh raſcall.

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.l: my
Young Landlord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Let him alone, the law
Shall puniſh him, but ſirra where did you poiſon
Him.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: About a dayes iourney hence, as he was
Comming hom from Athens I met him, and
Poiſoned him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But ſirrah who ſet you a worke
Confeſſe, I ſhall finde out the whole ne •• of there
Rogues, ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Count Virro hired me to do it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh lying Raſcall.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.p: Nay he that will ſteale will lye.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: Ile beleeue nothing he ſayes.

sp.speaker: 3. Wat.
sp.p: Be lye a man of worſhip.

sp.speaker: 4. Wat.
sp.l: A noble man

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away with him, Ile heare no more, remit him to
Priſon; Sirrah, you ſhall heare of theſe things
To morrow, where you would be loath to heare vm.
Come lets goe. exeunt.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Franklin, Shallow, Luce, Franciſco in a Parſons habit, and a true Parſon otherwiſe attyred.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: ILe take your counſell Sir, Ile not be ſeene in't, but meete you when tis done, youle marry them.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Feare not that Sir, Ile doe the deede.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I ſhall reſt thankfull to you, till then Ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I pray father leaue vs, wee know how to behaue our ſelues alone, mee thinkes Luce wee are too many by two yet.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are merry Sir. exeunt manet Franklin.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now they are ſure or neuer, poore Franciſco
Thou metſt thy match, when thou durſt vndertake
To ouerreach me with tricks, wher's now your Sumner?
Fore heauen I cannot but applaud my braine,
To take my daughter euen againſt her will,
And great with child by another, her ſhame publiſht,
She cited to the Court, and yet beſtow her
On ſuch a fortune as rich Shallow is,
Nay that which is the Maſter-peece of all,
Make him beleeue 'tis his, though he nere toucht her,
If men nere met with croſſes in the world,
There were no difference twixt the wiſe and fooles,
〈◊〉 ile goe meete vm, when tis done, I feare not. exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay fret not now, you haue beene worſe abuſd
If you had married her, ſhe neuer lou'd you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I euer ſcorn'd thy folly and hated thee, though
Sometimes afore my father I would make an Aſſe
Of thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Oh women, monſtrous women,
Little does her father know who has married her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, he knowes the Parſon married me,
And you can witneſſe that.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And he ſhall know the Parſon will lye with her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well Parſon, I will be reuenged on all thy coate,
I will not plough an Acre of ground for you to
Tyth, Ile rather paſture my neighbours cattle
For nothing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Oh be more charitable Sir, bid God giue vm ioy.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I care not greatly if I do, he is not the firſt
Parſon that has taken a gentlemans leauings.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: You gueſſe my meaning, I hope to haue good luck
To horſe-fleſh now ſhe is a Parſons wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You haue laine with her then Sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I cannot tell you that, but if you ſaw a woman with child without lying with a man, then perhaps I haue not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Impudent Coxcombe, dareſt thou ſay that euer thou layſt with mee, didſt thou euer ſo much as kiſſe my hand in priuate.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Theſe things muſt not be ſpoken of in company.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt I euer hated thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But when you were i'th good humour you would tell me another tale.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The foole is mad, by heauen my Franciſco I am wrong'd. He diſcouers himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then I muſt change my note, ſirrah, vnſay
What you haue ſpoken, ſweare here before
The Parſon and my ſelfe, you neuer toucht her, or
Ile cut thy throat, it is Franciſco threatens thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I am in a ſweete caſe, what ſhould I doe now, h ••
Father thinkes I haue laine with her, if I deny it
Heele haue about with me, if I ſay I haue, this
Young rogue will cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come will you ſweare.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I would I were fairely off, I would loſe my wench with all my heart, I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, now thou art free from any imputation that his tongue can ſtick vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well now I ſee tis do • e.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Her's one
Shall 〈◊〉 with you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: God giue you ioy ſonne

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thanke you father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: How' • this, Franciſco in the Parſons habite,

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: I haue married her as you bad me Sir, but this
Was th • truer Parſon of the two, he tyed the
〈◊〉 and this Gentleman is our witneſſe▪

sp.p: 〈…〉 vndone, Strumpet thou haſt betraied thy 〈…〉 beggery, to ſhame beſide • , and that in open Court, 〈…〉 what thou haſt ſought, hang, beg, and ſtarue, ile 〈…〉 .
Good Sir.
I told you what would come on't.
How did your wiſedome loſe her?
〈…〉 you ſee▪ I was beguild, and ſo were you.
〈◊〉 take her, thou ſeeſt the portion thou art like • o ha • e.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis ſuch a portion as will euer pleaſe 〈…〉 for her ſake be not vnnaturall.
Do not reiect me father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
But for the fault 〈…〉 were for, or ſhame ſhee ſhould endure in 〈◊〉 , behold her yet an vntoucht Virgin, Cuſhion come 〈…〉
Shallow, take your child vnto you, make 〈…〉 proue as wiſe as the father.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: This is more ſtrange then •• ther, ah Luce, we ••
〈◊〉 ſo ſubtill to deceiue thy ſelfe, and me; well
〈…〉 , tis thine owne choiſe.

sp.p:
Sir we can force no bounty from you, and there
•••• muſt reſt content with what your pleaſure is.

〈…〉 he is my Lord, that's he in the Parſons 〈…〉 thus diſguiſd about the buſineſſe I told you of
Lyſandro, ſee your noble father.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Welcome my long loſt ſonne from all the ſtormes
Of frowning fortune that thou haſt endur'd
Into thy fathers armes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I • my Franciſco noble.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord Euphues ſonne, I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.p: I heare Lyſandro that you are married.

sp.speaker: Franciſco.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, this is my Bride, the Daughter and Heyre of this rich Gentleman, twas onely ſhe that when my ſtate was nothing, my poore ſelfe and Parentage vnknowne, vouchſaf't to know, nay grace mee with her loue, her conſtant loue.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Such merit muſt not be forgot my ſonne,
Daughter much ioy attend vpon your choiſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now wants but your conſent.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Which with a willing heart I do beſtow,
Pardon me worthy ſonne, I haue ſo long
Beene hard to you, twas ignorance
Of what you were, and care I tooke for her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your care •• edes no Apo • ogy.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: But now Lyſandro I muſt make thee ſad
Vpon thy wedding day, and let thee know
There is no pure and vncompounded ioy
Lent to 〈◊〉 , in depth of woe
Thou 〈◊〉 the knowledge of thy parentage,

Thy elder 〈…〉
Philocles muſt dye,
And 〈…〉 , our name and houſe
Had 〈…〉 euer, had not gracious heauen
Sent as a 〈◊〉 to my 〈◊〉 age,
Thy long loſt ſelfe ſupporter of the name.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: But can there • e no meanes to ſaue his life.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: 〈…〉 none, the King has tane an oath
Neuer to 〈◊〉 him, but ſince they ſay
His 〈◊〉 r • pents, and faine would ſaue him.
Then 〈◊〉 wretched, like a man long blind,
That comes at laſt 〈◊〉 ſee the wiſht for ſonne,
But finde it in ecclipſe, ſuch is my caſe,
To meete in this darke woe my deareſt friends,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Had you not heard this newes before Lyſandro?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and did lament,
As for a worthy ſtranger, but nere knew
My ſorrow ſtood engag'd by ſuch a tye
As brotherhood, where may we ſee him Sir?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: This morning hee's arraign'd, put of that habite
You are in, and goe along with me, leaue your
Friends heare awhile.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell father,
Deare Luce till ſoone farewell, nought but ſo ſad
A chaunce, could make mee cloudy now. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Frank:
sp.l: Well Luce thy choice has proued better then we
Expected, but this cloud of griefe has dimde
Our mirth, but will I hope blow ouer,
Heauen graunt it may.
And ſignior Shallow, though you haue miſt what
My loue meant you once, pray be my gueſt.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir, Ile not be ſtrange. Exeunt

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nicanor, I would find ſome priuy place
Where I might ſtand vnſeene, vnknowne of any,
To heare the arraignment of yong Philocles.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: The Iudges are now entring, pleaſe you Sir
Heere to aſcend, you may both heare and ſee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well Ile goe vp,
And like a iealous husband heere and ſee
That that will ſtrike me dead, am I a King
And cannot pardon ſuch a ſmall offence,
I cannot doo't, nor am I Caeſar now,
Luſt ha • vncrown'd me, and my raſh tane oath
H • s 〈◊〉 of a Kings prerogatiue,
Come come Nicanor, helpe me to aſcend,
And • ee that fault that I want power to mend. Aſcendant

stage.hi:
〈◊〉
▪ Iudges, Virro, Polimetes, Euphues, Franciſco, Leucothoe, Clerimont, Roſcio.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.p: Bring forth the priſoner, where are the witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here my Lords, I am the wrong'd party,
And the fact my man, here beſides the Officers
That tooke them can iuſtifie.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.p: That's enough.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: Philocles ſtand to the Barre, and anſwere to ſuch
Crimes as ſhall be here obiected againſt thy life.
Reade the enditement.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Spare that labour,
I do confeſſe the fact that I am charg'd with,
And ſpeake as much as my accuſers can,
As much as all the witneſſes can proue,
Twas I that ſtole away the Daughter and Heire
Of the Lord Polimetes, which wert to doe againe
Rather then loſe her, I againe would venture,
This was the fact, your ſentence honour'd fathers.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Tis braue and reſolute.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: A heauy ſentence noble Philocles,
And ſuch a one, as I could wiſh my ſelfe
Off from this place, ſome other might deliuer,
You muſt dye for it, death is your ſentence.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Which I embrace with willingneſſe, now my Lord, to Pol.
Is your hate glutted yet, or is my life
Too poore a ſacrifice to appeaſe the rancor
Of your inueterate malice, if it be to
Inuent ſome ſcandall that may after blot
My reputation, father dry your teares,
Weepe not for me, my death ſhall leaue no ſtaine
Vpon your bloud, nor blot on your faire name▪
The honour'd aſhes of my anceſtors
May ſtill reſt quiet in their teare wet Vrnes
For any fact of mine, I might haue liu'd
If heauen had not preuented it, and found
Death for ſome foule diſhonourable act.
Brother farewell, no ſooner haue I found to Franciſco
But I muſt leaue thy wiſht for company.
Farewell my deareſt loue, liue thou ſtill happy,
And may ſome one of more deſert then I,
Be bleſt in the enioying what I looſe,
I neede not wiſh him happineſſe that has thee,
For 〈…〉 bring it may hee proue as good
〈…〉 worthy.
deareſt Philocles,
〈…〉 for any man but thee
〈…〉 good my Lords
〈…〉 both together
〈…〉 alike, why ſhould the law
〈…〉 and lay it all on him,
〈…〉 would we could as lawfully
〈…〉 hee ſhould not dye for this,
〈…〉 , whoſe that you haue brought there?
〈…〉 A benefactor, if it pleaſe your Lordſhips,
〈…〉 him in my watch laſt night.

sp.p: Wha • 's his offence?

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.p: murder.
No maſter Conſtable, twas but poiſoning of a man.
〈…〉 a foole.
〈…〉 for euer, all will out.
What proofes haue you againſt him?
His owne profeſſion if it pleaſe your honor.

sp.l: And 〈…〉 ill profeſſion, to be a murderer, thou
〈…〉 has confe •• the fact.

sp.p: Yes my Lord, hee cannot deny it.
Did he not name the party who it was that he had 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: marry with reuerance be it ſpoken.
〈…〉 my Lord Polimetes his ſonne.
How's this

sp.speaker: 1. Iu
sp.p: He di'd long ſence at Athens.

sp.l: I cannot tell what I ſhould thinke of it,
〈…〉 the man that lately brought me newes
〈…〉 to the barre, thou 〈◊〉 thy accuſation
〈…〉 ſay.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ah my good Lord,
〈…〉 deny what I haue ſaide,
〈…〉 , as my bleeding heart
Was making confeſſion of my crime.
I told him an • ſhall pleaſe your Lordſhips
〈…〉 Kings officers had eies to heare ſuch raſcalls.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: You haue bin carefull in your office Conſtable,
You may now leaue your Priſoner,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ile leaue the fell on with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: Farewel good

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Murder I ſee will out. exit Con.
Why didſt thou poiſon him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I was poore,
And want made me be hir'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.p: Hir'd, by whom?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: By Count Ʋirro,
There he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: I do beſeech your Lordſhips not to credit
What this baſe fellow ſpeakes, I am innocent.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: I doe beleeue you are, ſirrah ſpeake truth,
You haue not long to liue.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Pleaſe it your Lordſhip
I may relate the manner.

sp.speaker: 3. Iu.
sp.p: doe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Eugenio was aliue when firſt the newes
Was ſpred in Syracuſe he was dead,
Which falſe report Count Virro crediting,
Became an earneſt ſuitor to his Siſter
Thinking her Heyre, but finding afterwards
Her brother liu'd, and comming home
Not a dayes iourney hence, he ſent me to him,
And with a promiſe of fiue hundred crownes
Hir'd me to poyſon him, that this is true
Heer's his owne hand to witneſſe it againſt him,
Pleaſe it your Lordſhips to peruſe the writing.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.p: This is his hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.l: Sure as I liue,
I haue ſeene Warrants from him with iuſt theſe
Carracters.

sp.speaker: 3. Iu.
sp.l: Beſides me thinkes this fellowes
Tale is likely.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Tis too true,
This fellowes ſuddaine going from my houſe
Put me into a feare.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: Count Virro, ſtand to the barre,
What can you ſay to cleere you of this murder?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Nothing my Lords, I muſt confeſſe the fact.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.l: Why then againſt you both doe I pronounce.
Sentence of death.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: The Law is iuſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Wretch that I am, is my diſſembled griefe
Turn'd to true ſorrow, were my acted teares
But Propheſies of my enſuing woe,
And is he truely dead. oh pardon me
De • ie Ghoſt of my Eugenio, twas my fault
That cal'd this haſty vengeance from the Gods,
And ſhortened thus thy life, for whilſt with tricks
•• ought to faſten wealth vpon our houſe,
•• rought a Canniball to be the graue
Of me and mine, baſe bloudy murderous Count.

sp.p: Vile Couſner, cheating Lord, diſſembler.

sp.speaker: • . Iu.
sp.l: Peace, ſtop the mouth of malediction there,
This is no place to raile in.
Ye iuſt powers,
•• at to the quality of mans offence,

•
•• pe your correcting rods, and puniſh there
Where he has ſinn'd, did not my bleeding heart
〈◊〉 ſuch a heauy ſhare in this dayes woe,
• could with a free ſoule applaud your iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lord Euphues and Philocles forgiue me
To make amends, I know's impoſſible
For what my malice wrought, but I would faine
〈…〉 that might teſtifie my griefe
〈…〉 repentance.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: This is that I look't for.

sp.l: Y •• re kind too late my Lord, had you bin thus
〈…〉 required, y'had ſau'd your ſelfe and me,
〈…〉 ſonnes, but if your griefe be true
〈…〉 you heartily.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And I,
Now comes my que, my Lord Polimetes,
〈…〉 correction let me aske one queſtion.

sp.p: What queſtion? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: if this young Lord
〈…〉 , would you beſtow your Daughter
〈…〉 vpon him, would you Lord?

sp.p: As willingly as I would breath my ſelfe.

sp.l: Then dry all your eyes,
〈…〉 heare ſhall haue a cauſe to weeke, to Phil.
〈…〉 , Leucothoe is no Heire,
〈…〉 liues, and that cleares you Count Virro
〈…〉 murder.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How, liues?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Yes liues to call thee brother Philocles.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Oh my deare Brother.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My ſonne,
Welcome from death.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Pardon me good my Lord that I thus long
Haue from your knowledge kept my ſelfe conceal'd,
My end was honeſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I ſee twas,
And now ſonne Philocles giue mee thy hand,
Heere take thy wife, ſhe loues thee I dare ſweare,
And for the wrong that I intended thee,
Her portion ſhall be double what I meant it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Brother Euphues,
I hope all enmity is now forgot
Betwixt our houſes.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Let it be euer ſo, I do embrace your loue.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Well my life is ſau'd yet, though my wench be loſt,
God giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thankes good my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1. Iu.
sp.l: How ſuddenly this tragicke ſceane is charg'd,
And turn'd to Comedy

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.p:
Tis very ſtrange.
The King ſpeakes from 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Let vs conclude within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay,
And take my ioy with you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: His Maieſty
Is comming downe, let vs attend. Enter King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Theſe iarres are well clos'd vp, now Philocles,
What my raſh oath deni'de me, this bleſt how • e
And happy accident has brought to paſſe,
The ſauing of thy life.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A life my Leige,
That ſhall be euer ready to be ſpent
Vpon your ſeruice.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thankes good Philocles,
But wher's the man whoſe happy preſence brought
All this vnlook't for ſport: where is Eugenio?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Heere my dread Leige.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome to 〈…〉
Welcome Eugenio, prithee aske ſome boone
That may requite the good that thou haſt done.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I thanke your Maieſty, what I haue done
Needes no requitall, but I haue a ſuite
Vnto Lord Euphues, pleaſe it your Maieſty
To be to him an inte • ceſſor for me,
I make no queſtion but I ſhall obtaine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What is it? ſpeake, it ſhall be granted thee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That it would pleaſe him to beſtow on me
His Neece, the faire and vertuous Lady Laeda.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: With all my heart, I know 'twill pleaſe her well,
I haue often heard her praiſe Eugenio,
It ſhall be done within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then here all ſtrife ends,
Ile be your gueſt my ſelfe to day, and helpe
To ſolemnize this double marriage.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Your royall preſence ſhall much honour vs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then leade away, the happy knot you tye,
Concludes in loue two houſes enmity.

div.head: EPILOGVS.
div.l: OVr Authors heire if it be legitimate
Tis his, if not, he dares the worſt of fate,
For if a Baſtard, charity is ſuch,
That what you giue, it cannot be too much,
And he, and we, vow if it may be ſhowne,
To doe as much for yours, as for our owne.
